qas.question: Who grants a charitable status to an NPO in Canada?
What are donors to receive from a NPO?
How does an NPO keep their charitable status?
How does the Canada Revenue Agency decide who can have a charitable status?

answers.text: a common law test to its stated objects and activities

qas.question: What kinds of assets must the NPO spend in order to keep it's charitable status?
How do donors keep their assets?
What is the CRA allowed to issue to donors?

plausible_answers.text: CRA applies a common law test to its stated objects and activities

qas.question: How do fixed assets determine an NPO's status?

plausible_answers.text: a certain percentage of their assets (including cash, investments and fixed assets)

qas.question: What are donors required to spend in Canada?
What test must be taken for a NPO to keep its status?

context: Canada also permits a variety of charities (including public and private foundations). Charitable status is granted by the <a0_0>Canada Revenue Agency (CRA)<a0_0/> upon application by a nonprofit; charities are allowed to issue <a1_0><b6_0>income tax receipts<b6_0/><a1_0/> to donors, must spend <b8_0>a certain percentage of their assets (including <a4_0>cash, investments and fixed assets<a4_0/>)<b8_0/> and <a2_0><b5_0>file annual reports<b5_0/><a2_0/> in order to maintain their charitable status. In determining whether an organization can become a charity, <b7_0>CRA applies <a3_0><b9_0>a common law test<b9_0/> to its stated objects and activities<b7_0/><a3_0/>. These must be:
